Initiating character resonance.\nBiological homeostasis. No abnormalities detected.
Initiating bookshelf restoration.\nBookmark acquisition complete.
The verse is complete.\n“Welcome to the Worst World.”

The city where the religious leader resided was thought to be the closest place to heaven, and so attracted a great many pilgrims.\nDevout as I was, I took up my halberd and stood before the gates of the holy city to watch out for any suspicious wanderers.

I kept a careful watch for anyone who could have been a pagan spy or a dealer of forbidden articles.\nWhen I saw anyone who fit the bill, I approached them to halt their activities...by any means necessary.

Old and accomplished veteran that I was, the younger guards would come running to me whenever I stood in front of the gate and insist that they take my place.\nI wish I could say I can still hold my own, but it's time I acknowledge my age and step aside for the next generation.

I heard something from my family.
An arm injury had forced a former holy knight tasked with defending the holy city into an early retirement.
Seeing himself as a knight of the gods, he was consumed by wild delusions that it was still his job to protect the city.
Well, I suppose he's not doing any harm... May as well let him live whatever life he has left on his own terms.

My first impression of this weapon that came from a faraway land was "rustic." Its handle was rusted, it had a strange mechanism, and the blade was deformed. It had been sold as a spear, but it was too heavy for that. Is this something that was really worth anything...?\n

His Majesty presented us with quite the demand—"I will handsomely reward anyone who brings me the heaviest weapon in three days' time." He wants to use it to nominate heroes, apparently, but frankly? I couldn't care less about his insane requests. That's when the gods blessed me with a heavy spear. It was just lying in a junkyard.

When an enemy nation is conquered, you take their weapons as proof of your victory. I can't imagine the land of vanquished giants this monstrous spear came from. The king was gripping it tightly as he pleaded for his life, kneeling in his own piss. Once would think it'd be worth something, but when I took it in to be appraised, I was told it was absolute trash. So much for that.\n

There was a prince who suffered from a terrible shyness. His father, the king, had made his name as a great villain. He knew that his days were numbered and so started to prepare for when he was gone.\nHe sent a letter to a merchant and a few days later he received a mask.\nIt was apparently a magical item that could transform the character of its wearer.

The prince put the mask on and his fear slipped away.\n"This mask is only temporary. I will make myself stronger so I do not rely on it. I will overcome my difficulties," he said to his father. And with that his father could rest in peace.

The prince followed in his father's footsteps to become king, but he was aware that his capabilities fell far short of his father's.\nHe did what he could to not be afraid of governance, but most times he could not do it without the aid of his mask.

He wore the mask so often, that at some point it became a part of him. He lost his gentle nature and he became an arrogant person.\nHe angered kingdoms who had been close allies since the days of his father. When people plotted against him, he burned the castle and ordered cruel executions.
“Eating.”\nIt’s a natural part of life. \nBut “to eat” means something unique only to us.
“Just right.” \nOne person’s definition of what’s “just right” might not match someone else’s.\nIt’s a vague state of being.
But what does it mean to be “just right?” \nAnd whose opinion matters most?
That, I don’t know. \nWhatever it is, all I know is that it means everything to us.

In a far-off island nation to the east, there was a kingdom whose nautical might was second to none. The people there lived with hearts that were pure, just, and beautiful, and the island had never known a defeat in written history. \nThe captain there was a peerless man who wielded a mace.

The warrior was not only brave of heart, but noble and beloved by all. \nVoices clamored for the decorated warrior to be named the military leader of the land,\nbut he would quiet them each time, saying, “It is not in me to rule.”

When a foreign ship came carrying a commercial treaty to the ruler of the island nation, he unilaterally struck it down. \nIn retaliation, a warship from the Four Seas surged upon the kingdom, and her naval forces were driven to the brink of destruction.\nThe night before what would surely be their final table, battle, the fearless captain bade his men to drink and make merry, saying, “Let us protect this pure, beautiful land until the bitter end!”

That very night, the warrior was bound tightly in his sleep and shoved into a coffin, beloved mace and all. \nThey heaved the coffin from the edge of the ship and watched it sink into the dark depths of the sea below. \n“We never would have gone to war, if only you’d agreed to rule,” his subordinates spat, then went to their enemy, waving a white flag of surrender.
A tune echoes in the midnight forest; beautiful, yet somehow sad. \nSuch is the music that soothes the souls of the departed.

In living life they sought fame and glory.
Now, their ambitions left unfulfilled,
these forlorn souls continue their aimless journey through the dark forest,
never to be the protagonists of their own worlds.
The instrument plays its song, \nreviving memories of past glories\n and soothing their troubled souls.
Yet the song is brought to an abrupt end by a melody that foretells a tragedy…… Just as abruptly as their lives were cut short.
By the grace of the gods, \nyou have the right to be happy.
By the grace of the gods, you deserve to be surrounded by friends and those you love, and to be blessed with an enriched life.
By the grace of the gods, you will never go hungry, nor will you shiver from cold or swelter from heat.
By the grace of the gods, you are allowed to live. \nRejoice, rejoice, rejoice.

The spearman made his way to challenge the water serpent of the lake. They fought and fought, evenly matched, until the spearman launched himself—spear, man, and all—into the serpent’s great maw in a last act of desperation.\nMan and snake alike sank into the water’s depths, and neither emerged for some time.

In the dead of night, the water reflected the moon as it hung in the night sky. Ripples formed on the glass-still surface, growing in intensity until the spearman’s head at last burst through the water. He raised the tip of his spear victoriously. “I’ve done it!” he howled. “I’ve slain the water serpent!”

The spear-man’s fame spread far and wide. \nHowever, one day he happened upon a startling discovery: whether he was on the battlefield, sitting down to eat, or sleeping with a beautiful woman, water had begun to slowly drip from his body.

He began to eat less and less.\nOne morning, he woke to find he had transformed into a soft, cold-blooded creature. \nThe water serpent made a vow: if there was no place for him among the humans, he would return to his mother lake……

Many admired this man in his dauntless pursuit of strength and entreated him to take them under his wing. \nBut he turned them all away, retreating to the mountains to dedicate himself to his training instead.

One stormy day, the warrior vanished as he arduously trained at the mountain’s summit, leaving only his naginata behind. \nLegend has it that the gods were so enamored with his noble soul that demons spirited him off to the heavens…… but ultimately, the truth is unknown.
A sacred bird lived on a holy mountain.\nThis bird was considered an angel of god and was said to watch over the earth from the edge of the heavens.

There was also a hunter.\nSeveral decades ago he had spied this bird on a pilgrimage to the holy peak and had become obsessed.\nHe made it his life’s mission to shoot it down, so he started tracking the creature.

One day, the hunter finally caught up to the bird. A single arrow through the air took out its wing.\nHe shot a second arrow and a third, but he slipped and fell over a cliff face.\nWith that, he met his end.

Later, a passing traveler discovered an abandoned bow.\nFeeling fearful of the form representing the sacred bird, he created a little tomb and interred it there.\nThe witch of the village declared that it was a divine weapon, melding the spirit of the hunter and the spirit of the bird together. It has long now been an object of faith.

A blade unearthed from the wasteland.
Too big to be called a sword, too heavy to fight with, too ugly to be cermonial.
What was it for?
It left the archaeologists scratching their heads.

When they researched the site where the blade was dug up, and referenced documents from the same time period,
they came upon a story about the blade.
The knight who had owned the blade
had single-handedly wiped out two whole enemy kingdoms.

They analyzed the blade to find out what it was made of, and to their surprise,
they found it contained not only steel, but also human blood and bits of bone.
The archaeologists believed the blade had been made of the weapons and bodies of dead men,
to serve as a warning against war.

War broke out, and the archaeologists found out the tale was true.
The knight appeared in the storeroom where the blade was kept, exactly as the ancient documents described him.

They would never rest, explained the knight, until humanity realized the foolishness of war.
My name is the Black Book. Are you the king who will lead the world to salvation? Don't be so surprised, Your Majesty. For me, it is a simple matter to speak human words.

I sympathize with your distress, Your Majesty. On this occasion, however, we have no choice but to let them deal with your sister. When sorrow overtakes you, you may come to me and speak of your tribulations.
Reading is an admirable pursuit. Your Majesty—for me?? I shall peruse this volume if it comes on your recommendation... What is that? You think it odd for a book to read a book?

Noir? I would prefer to dispense with this nickname. My name, Your Majesty, is the Black Book. I am a grand tome of human wisdom... thus, to refer to me by such a curious moniker is, dare I say, inappropriate.

The people in the church murmured prayers, their eyes fixed on an ominous stone carving of a bull's head. A solemn atmosphere hung over the chapel. The worshipers were praying to select a sacrifice to offer to god. Following a long silence, the priest announced the sacred mandate: a shy young girl would serve as the sacrifice. Tears streamed down her cheeks as the priest let her down a corridor into the inner sanctum.

The crowd filed out, and silence settled again over the chapel. A boy stood there in a daze. He had been the childhood playmate of the girl who had been chosen as the sacrifice, and he had always had a crush on her. She was so shy, so quiet, and he was determined to watch over her. He could never forget the memory of her smiling face, which she had shown to him alone. After making sure the coast was clear, the boy crept into the inner sanctum.

At the end a dimly lit corridor, the boy spied a light on inside a room. He peeked in and saw the girl all alone, crying. The boy took her hand, and they ran from the church. It's okay, it's okay, I'll never leave you, he gently assured her as she sobbed, shoulders heaving. But the girl did not respond. She just hung her head, mumbling beneath her breath.\n

The girl’s voice gradually got louder and finally turned to screams. "God, at last, you've chosen me! Give me all your love, more and more and more and more and..." As tears of joy streamed down her face, she drew out the sharp bull's horn she had secreted away and stabbed herself in the heart. The bloodstained bull's horn gleamed vividly, looking almost alive. \n

The man went to war for the sake of his beloved wife. On the battlefield, his chest was slashed and his belly was split open, but nothing could bring him to his knees. He was an immortal warrior. He wasn't gifted with any special physical ability, so if he weren't immortal, how could he have made it through?

The man had been immortal since he crossed paths with a small, beautiful bird one fateful day. Moved by the man's devotion to his wife, the bird had said to him, holding out a feather, "Carry this feather with you, and you will live to see your loved one again."

When the war ended, the man collected his payment and returned to live with his wife in the village. They lived in such poverty he couldn’t even afford clothes for his wife. Nonetheless, his love for her gave him a reason to live.

Once again, the man went to war for the sake of his beloved wife. On the battlefield, his chest was slashed and his belly was split open, and he fell down dead. That very day, back in the village, the man's wife had gone to a merchant and sold his beloved beautiful bird feather.

Flames swallowed the house, leaping up as if to burn the black night sky. The boy barely escaped, but his father, his mother, his siblings, and everything he owned went up in flames. All the boy was left with was a battleaxe the bandits had left behind, and the burn marks on his body. He waited for the wounds to heal, cursing the gods for condemning him to this fate.

The boy grew up to be a man, but still the burns did not heal. He tried all types of medicine, but there seemed to be no hope of recovery. Each time he brushed away the maggots gnawing on the scars, the pain would flare back up, and he would sink into a foul mood. Searching for a way to forget the pain, the young man joined a band of mercenaries. He realized that the moment his sword descended on an enemy, then and only then did the pain ease. He had finally found an escape from his suffering.

Hired to fight in a conflict with a neighboring kingdom, the mercenaries laid waste to an enemy village. The young man wildly swung the battleax, determined to force his pain on others, to drown his suffering in the murderous ecstasy of war. He burst inside a home, beheaded the father as he pleaded for his life, hacked the mother's body to bits while shouting curses, and tossed the baby into the burning stove. For a short time, he forgot the pain of the burns.

Swept up in the ecstasy of slaughter, he lit fire to the room where the corpses lay, just for fun. On his way out, he spied a young girl standing near the burning home, crying. The moment he laid eyes on her, he remembered the fire of his youth that had taken everything from him, and the pain of the burn wounds flared up. Understanding there was only one way to end this suffering, he lit himself on fire, and handed the bloodstained battleax to the girl.
The king sung the praises\nof the eternal kingdom and the sun that would never set.
The queen sung the praises\nof the great king and his marvelous achievements.
The prince sung the praises\nof the staunchly loyal soldiers, always marching forward.
The jester just sung a song,\nridiculing the three members of the royal family who had rested on their laurels and met their doom.
She was slender, with smooth, white skin.\nThe hint of a dark shadow in her expression highlighted her beautiful features.\nBut something about the sword in her hand didn't seem to fit the picture.
Anger, sorrow, hatred.\nWhen emotions overwhelmed her, she would swing the sword, so there was never a lack of blood to quench its thirst.\nThe problem was that she couldn't put the sword down.
A heart and body in constant conflict.\nNo one in the world could understand her.\nAnd loneliness was eating her alive.
The long war came to an end, and darkness devoured her.\nBut her heart remained at peace.\nBecause she faced fate in the arms of the one she loved.
